column1: Move Indy-Agent issues from INDY and IS projects
column27: We need to migrate existing agent issues from the indy-sdk and indy-node project JIRA repositories (INDY and IS) into this new location.

This is the main issue to house tasks related to creating the indy-agent. indy-agent will serve as a reference of how to implement an agent using libindy and indy-sdk. It will also be used to test the completeness of the Sovrin protocol.

Discussion about the reference agent will be held on the #indy-agent on Rocket.chat.

column27:
The python agent currently stores a DID as a key identifier for a connection. There has been discussion to store a nonce instead. Type is a ambiguous topic currently, but must be stored.
Message structure should reflect something similar to this.
\{
     id :< nonce | DID >,

     type : ,

     message : ,
}

*This issue is a little too general to be useful; I'm marking it as done for now.*


Story: As a user, I want an interactive interface that allows me to: 
       open a wallet - -IS-768-
       manage connections - IA-9,
       manage credentials -
       manage chat messages -
 so that I have a working example of sovrin protocols.

Story: As a user, I want an example of a python agent server that has: 
      security packaging - IA-17
      routing handler - IA-19
      modules - IA-20
so that I have a working agent server example for the sovrin network.

How to demo:
Show all linked tasks are done.

Story: As a user, I want to be able to manage my connections (relationships) by: 
* viewing connections - IA-12 , IA-13 
* viewing connections active history - IA-11 , IA-10
* requesting a connection - 
* accepting/rejecting a connection - IA-14
 so that my connections are manageable and their state is transparent.

To demo this:
Show that each referenced task is completed.

Story: As a user, I want to be able to view an ordered list of events that have occurred in each of my connections (relationships), so that my connections and their transactions are transparent. 

This could be implemented by updating a histoy/timeline view when a connection is selected. 

How to demo this:
Show the ability to select each connection individually and have the historic view update accordingly.

Story: As a user I want to view a connections history.

The ui needs a place to display a connections history. This will be used to display a connection's timeline which in the future will include, connection request date, connection accepted date, and an ordered list of messages in plain text with corresponding timestamps.

How to demo this:
Given an ordered list of events from a connections history, print them on the UIs history view, in historic order, with the ability to scroll.

Story: As a user, I want to view all my connections.

Python-agent needs a place to list a users connections. 

To demo this:
Given a list of connections, display them in a designated place on the UI.

Story: As a user I want a visual display of a connections state.

When a connection is displayed there should be a visual representation of its state, this could be a shading for requested and request connections with established connections having no shading. 

To demo this:
Give a visual indicator of the state/status of a connection in the UI.

Story: As a user I want to be able to accept or reject a connection/relationship request.

Each connection has a status, requested, request, established.  When a connection state is request, there should be a button that allows a user to accept that connection, all other connections should have a reject button.

To demo this:
Correctly display a bottom on all connections that can be pressed.  (This task does not require the button to do anything.)

column1: As a CLI user I should be able to send a connection request to another Identity Owner (institution or individual)
column27: Given I am a CLI user, I should be able to: 1. Sent a connection request to another Identity Owner (either an individual or organization).So that I can start having Sovrin Connections.Examples: -Joe requests to have a connection with Alice-A bank requests having a connection with Alice-Susan sends a connection request to Alice.Alice just a very popular person.*POA*_Assumptions_* Sender knows receiver's endpoint (for example: If Joe want to send connection request to Alice, then Joe already knows endpoint of Alice's agent)_POA Steps_* CLI user can add endpoint, identifier and other information with name to whom it wants to send connection request. Add a command in sovrin cli. In file sovrin/cli/cli.py, add regex to interpret cli command, add it to lexers and completers. Add command action handler.* In add connection name command handler, save data in available connections variable along with endpoint data. This will be used to send invitation to connections available.* Add `send invitation to <connection name>` command. Add a command in sovrin cli. In file sovrin/cli/cli.py, add regex to interpret cli command, add it to lexers and completers. Add command action handler.* In `send invitation` command handler, generate a unique nonce, save this nonce so that once other cli user accepts invitation, we can match it up. Generate an invitation file on runtime and send it to endpoint provided.* Add handler in agent which listens for incoming invitations. Allow CLI to register to this event, so that agent can forward this request to CLI running and CLI can print it out, so that user can take an action.

column1: As a CLI user I should be able to approve a connection request
column27: Given I've received a connection request: 1. I should be able to see that I have a connection request1.1 I should be able to see information about the requester 2. I should be able to approve/accept the connection request3. The requester should be notified that I accepted the connection request. 4. If I "deny" the connection request, nothing should happen.5. If I accept the connection request, I should have a secure connection established between me (the CLI user) and the other Identity (could be another CLI user acting as another institution or individual Identity Owner).Suggested text for incoming connection request: "New connection request from [requester's DID OR user-friendly name for that DID]. Type "approve" to approve or "deny" to deny. Type "request connection help" for more information."6. Typing "request connection help" should show me some more helpful information about what approving or denying a connection does. Some example explaining text: "Approving a connection request will add the requester to your list of connections. You can message and share verifiable claims and proofs with connections.""Denying a request will ignore the connection request, and the requester will not be notified.""You can remove a connection by typing [__________]"*POA*_Assumptions_* Incoming connection request handler add connection request to link in the same way as `load` command adds info to links._POA steps_* Once user sees any incoming connection request in CLI. User can issue an `accept invitation` command.* Check if receiver user is not a SPONSOR, then we can't add incoming identifier on sovrin, in this case use incoming identifier as it is.

column27:
Story: As a user, I want to be able to manage my credentials by:
 * viewing my credentials and their status - IA-47
 * send/receive a credential offer - (tasks to be added)
 * send/receive a credential request - (tasks to be added)
 * send/receive a credential - (tasks to be added)

Note #1: This is an implementation of Indy's Anoncreds, which allows the Reference Agent to be an Issuer, Prover, and Verifier.
 [https://github.com/hyperledger/indy-sdk/tree/master/doc/design/002-anoncreds]

Note #2: This module heavily implies the parallel implementation of the Proofs module. The Credentials module outlined here can can cover issuing and holding credentials, but proving and verifying credentials should be handled by the Proofs module. Proofs are essentially a more specific case of Credentials, but the abstraction is still a useful one because of the added functionality needed.

To demo this:
 Show that each referenced task is completed.

column1: Evernym contribute a reference cloud agent
column27:
*Story*
As a user of a solution in the Indy ecosystem, I need a constantly connected cloud agent to ensure that my mobile edge agent does not miss important notifications.

*Acceptance Criteria*
* Code is made part of public repositories in the Indy project.
*  A binary package exists which can be executed with "java -jar cloudagent.jar"
* The process runs a single cloud agent which can communicate with an open source edge agent such as the [Sovrin Connector App|https://github.com/sovrin-foundation/connector-app/]
* It includes manual build scripts sufficient for developers to work on the code base.
* It runs on Ubuntu Linux 16.04
* Unit tests are included and can be manually executed by a developer.
* Unit tests pass.
* JIRA issues exist that document open issues and key decisions regarding what we did and what we decided not to do.
* An architectural overview document, including an FAQ, is included in the code repository.
* A CI / CD pipeline is running on Hyperledger infrastructure that builds and executes the unit tests.

*Notes*
* The open source cloud agent needs to be sufficient for a technical person to run an agent for themselves on their own equipment.
* It is expected to be implemented in Scala.
* When agents are communicating with other agents, it is assumed that a mediator could be routing the messages.

*Excluded*
These efforts are future work:
* Removing dependency on Dynamo DB: IA-55
* Agent to agent protocol compatibility: IA-53
column60: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column100: 18/Sep/19 11:40 PM;esplinr;BC.gov contributed their VON agent as the Aries-Cloud-Agent-Python (ACA-py), removing the need for this effort by Evernym.;;;

column1: Move cloud agent code to the Indy Agent repository
column27:
The Indy Agent repository should contain a reference cloud agent.

*Acceptance Criteria*
* Move code from Evernym's Git repository to the Hyperledger repository  for Indy Agent.
* The code will be contributed as a pull request with proper DCO signatures so it is released under the Apache license.
* The code will build and unit tests will pass (see IA-49).
* It contains a README describing the purpose and use of the artifact.

Excluded:
* Code history is not required.
* Other tasks beyond contributing the code will be tracked as separate tickets.

*Acceptance Criteria*
* A document exists in the Indy Agent code repository describing the Reference Cloud Agent.
* Document should be in Markdown
* Define the design trade-offs made in development.
* Explaining essential alternative approaches that were not approved (anti-patterns and dead-ends in development)

column1: Cloud agent should not depend on Dynamo DB
column27:
*Story*
As an administrator maintaining a reference cloud agent, I want to use open source components to administer my deployment rather than having to subscribe to AWS Dynamo DB.

*Acceptance Criteria*
* The reference cloud agent can be configured to use an open source key-value store, such as Cassandra or MongoDB.

*Notes*
* An alternative implementation would be for it to manage it's key-value store in the same storage as the wallet, but that likely would take a lot of work.

column27:
The Reference Cloud Agent should be built and tested as part of the Indy Agent delivery pipeline.

*Acceptance Criteria*
Each time changes are made to the code repository:
* A jar is built
* Unit tests are executed
* Artifacts are published to Sovrin maven repo
